The "Fake-Ally Opponent" step refers to a character or group of characters who initially appear to be allies or friends to the main characters, but later turn out to be an obstacle or an enemy. They could be a potential source of conflict and tension in the story.

In your story, one example of a Fake-Ally Opponent could be other survivors who come to the bed and breakfast seeking shelter. At first, the main characters may welcome them and try to help them, but as time goes on, these survivors may become a burden on the main characters and their resources. They may not share the same ideas and values, and this could create conflicts and tensions between the main characters and these survivors.

Another example could be a character who joins the main characters on their journey but later reveals that they have their own agenda, or they are hiding something that can harm the main characters. This type of opponent can create a sense of betrayal and mistrust, and it can add an element of surprise and tension to the story.

The Fake-Ally Opponent can be a great way to add complexity and depth to the story, and to create a sense of uncertainty and danger for the main characters. It can also serve as a reminder that not everyone is who they appear to be, and that the main characters need to be cautious and to trust their instincts.

Perhaps Chris and Anna could fit into the Fake-Ally Opponent category? They seem to get along with our main characters at first, but as the young couple becomes uncomfortable with our main characters and try to escape, Chris and Anna could become an opposition to our main characters.

Yes, that could work well. Chris and Anna could be a fitting example of a Fake-Ally Opponent in the story. At first, they seem to be friendly and in need of help, but as the story progresses, their discomfort with the main characters and their attempts to leave the bed and breakfast could create conflicts and tensions between them.

As they try to leave, they could reveal that they have their own agenda and that they don't trust the main characters. This revelation could be a turning point in the story, where the main characters have to reassess their relationship with Chris and Anna and decide whether to trust them or not.

Also, it could be interesting to explore the reasons behind their discomfort, it could be due to the main characters' bubbly personalities and the way they try to mask their grief, or it could be something deeper, perhaps they have some dark secrets or fears that they are hiding from the main characters.

The Fake-Ally Opponent is a powerful tool to add complexity and depth to the story and to create a sense of uncertainty and danger for the main characters. It can also serve as a reminder that not everyone is who they appear to be, and that the main characters need to be cautious and to trust their instincts.

Hmmm...I never considered that Chris and Anna could be hiding their own secret. At first, I just thought they would be uncomfortable with Edgar and Rachel's bubbly personalities and attachment to Indy. Now, I want to brainstorm possible secrets that Chris and Anna could be hiding.

There are many potential secrets that Chris and Anna could be hiding. Here are a few examples:

* They may have been responsible for the death of their own child before the apocalypse. This secret could be the reason why they feel uncomfortable around Edgar and Rachel, who have lost their own daughter.
* They could be former criminals or fugitives who are on the run from the law. This secret could be the reason why they are so secretive and why they are so eager to leave the bed and breakfast.
* They could be part of a group or a cult that has a different agenda and beliefs about how to survive the apocalypse. This secret could put them at odds with the main characters and create conflicts and tensions.
* They could be hiding a medical condition that makes them more vulnerable to the zombies, and they are afraid of being rejected by the main characters.
* They could have a hidden stash of supplies or weapons that they have been hiding from the main characters. This secret could be the reason why they are always in a hurry to leave and why they are unwilling to share their resources.

These are just a few examples of the kind of secrets that Chris and Anna could be hiding. The key is to make sure that whatever secret they're hiding is something that can drive the story forward and create conflicts and tensions between them and the main characters.
I think the secret should have something to do with Indy, their daughter.

Yes, that could work well. Having the secret have something to do with Indy, their daughter, could add depth and complexity to the story and create an emotional connection between the characters. Here are a few examples of how Indy could be related to the secret that Chris and Anna are hiding:

* Indy is not their biological child, and they are afraid of losing her or someone finding out. This secret could be the reason why they are so protective of her and why they are so uncomfortable around Edgar and Rachel, who have lost their own daughter.
* Indy is immune to the zombie, and they are hiding this information from others. They fear that if someone else knows this, they will take her away from them.
* Indy has a medical condition that makes her more vulnerable to the zombies, and they are hiding this information to protect her.
* Indy is the only surviving member of their family, and they are afraid of losing her, this can be the reason why they become overprotective and paranoid about her safety, and this could put them in conflict with Edgar and Rachel.
* They have had to do some terrible things to survive, and they are afraid that if someone finds out, they will be rejected or worse. This could be a reason why they are always in a hurry to leave and why they are unwilling to share their resources, especially with Indy.

In any case, having the secret be related to Indy will give the story more emotional depth and create a stronger connection between the characters, as well as conflicts and tensions that will drive the story forward.
I think I don't want Chris and Anna to have a dark secret anymore. I just want them to grow uneasy with Edgar and Rachel's bubbly personalities and their weird fascination with Indy.

That's fine too, it's important that you feel comfortable with the direction of your story. Having Chris and Anna grow uneasy with Edgar and Rachel's bubbly personalities and their weird fascination with Indy can also create conflicts and tension in the story. It can also serve as a mirror for the main characters, making them question their own behavior and how they are coping with their grief.

You could explore how Chris and Anna's discomfort with Edgar and Rachel's behavior can lead to a falling out, and how this falling out can lead to a climax where the young couple tries to leave the bed and breakfast. This conflict can be a turning point for the main characters and make them realize that they need to confront their grief and move on with their lives.

It's also important to remember that the story's primary focus should be the main characters, their struggles and their growth. The conflicts and tensions that arise from their interactions with other characters should be used to serve that main focus and help the main characters to progress in their journey.
So now step 9 of Truby's is "First Revelation and Decision: Changed Desire and Motive"

Yes, that's correct. Step 9, "First Revelation and Decision: Changed Desire and Motive," is an important step in the story where the main characters have a revelation about themselves, their situation or their relationships, and as a result, they make a decision that changes their desire and motive.

For Edgar and Rachel, this step could be the moment when they realize that they can't keep living in denial and that they need to confront their grief and move on with their lives. This realization could come as a result of their falling out with Chris and Anna, and the realization that they can't keep pretending that everything is okay.

This revelation could lead them to make a decision to leave the bed and breakfast, which symbolizes their life before the apocalypse and their daughter's death. This decision could be difficult for them as they have to let go of the past and the memories associated with the bed and breakfast.

This decision can also change their desire and motive, from trying to maintain a sense of normalcy and to keep the bed and breakfast running, to trying to find a new purpose and a new way of life. This new desire and motive could drive the story towards its resolution, where the main characters find closure and acceptance.

I want that mentioned change to come at the end of the story. It seems more fitting for "Self-Revelation." What other change can occur in step 9 that paves the way for the main characters' later self-revelation?

That's a good point, having the decision to leave the bed and breakfast and confront their grief come at the end of the story as a self-revelation makes more sense. In that case, step 9 could still be an important moment of change, but it could be a different kind of change that sets the stage for the main characters' eventual self-revelation.

Here are a few examples of how step 9 could be approached in this way:

* Edgar and Rachel could make a decision to try to protect Chris, Anna, and Indy from the zombies, even if it means putting themselves in danger. This decision could be a turning point for the main characters, as it forces them to confront their own mortality and the reality of the apocalypse.
* Edgar and Rachel could make a decision to reveal their grief and the loss of their daughter to Chris and Anna, which could help them connect with the young couple and understand their own behavior. This decision could be a step towards self-revelation and understanding the importance of confronting their grief.
* Edgar and Rachel could make a decision to open their bed and breakfast as a shelter for other survivors, despite the danger. This decision could be a step towards finding a new purpose and a new way of life, and it could serve as a catalyst for their eventual self-revelation.

In any case, step 9 should be a significant moment of change that sets the stage for the main characters' eventual self-revelation and their growth as individuals. It should be a turning point that leads the story towards its climax and resolution.
